Forensic mental health is the interface between the law and mental health. This
course examines the components of human behavior that bring people into a judicial
setting. Content includes: criminal personalities, forensic interview, and the role of
forensic psychiatry. Domestic violence offenders, sex offenders, stalkers, gang members,
and offenders who commit homicide are discussed. Definitions and dynamics of criminal
motherhood and the psychodynamics of violent juvenile offenders are presented. Use of
the internet by offenders is also discussed. This course also offers a field experience in
which student's interview incarcerated individuals.
Across the board students found the class “enjoyable” and “informative.” Many described
the course material as “very interesting” and able to stimulate students’ interest. Students
felt the combination of guest lecturers and testimonials in tandem with the lecture made
for a rewarding experience and overall a “great course”. Numerous students
recommended the course and described it as one of the best classes they have taken at
Penn.
Both the guest lecturers as well as the primary instructors were described as
“enthusiastic” and “engaging.” Students did not seem to seek out the professors’
guidance excessively, but were satisfied when they did.
This course is an elective and its workload reflects that. Students felt the required
assignments were not overwhelming and were adequate for the course content and style.
Many enjoyed the assignments. The main concern centered on grading. Some students
felt that grading guidelines were not clear and differed among the instructors.
